message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristic rash on the wrists and ankles suggests Lyme disease, which is treated with Doxycycline. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis, Vancomycin is used to treat bacterial infections, and Azithromycin is used to treat bacterial respiratory infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash on the wrists and ankles is consistent with a tick-borne illness, and the other symptoms suggest that it is likely Lyme disease. Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for Lyme disease. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis, Vancomycin is an antibiotic primarily used to treat bacterial infections, and Azithromycin is used to treat a variety of bacterial infections but is not the preferred treatment for Lyme disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and rash suggest that he has Lyme disease, which is treated with Doxycycline. Pyrazinamide is used for tuberculosis, vancomycin for bacterial infections, and azithromycin for respiratory infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms mentioned along with the rash on wrists and ankles suggest that the patient has Lyme disease, which is transmitted through tick bites. Doxycycline is the first-line antibiotic for treating Lyme disease. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis, vancomycin is used for bacterial infections, and azithromycin is used to treat respiratory and soft tissue infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine, which indicates that the patient is experiencing symptoms consistent with Lyme disease, which is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi transmitted by tick bites. Doxycycline is the first-line treatment for adults with Lyme disease, and should be initiated in this case. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis, and Vancomycin is used to treat bacterial infections of the skin and other tissues. Azithromycin is not an appropriate treatment for Lyme disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash on the wrists and ankles suggests Lyme disease, which is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria transmitted by Ixodes ticks. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for early localized Lyme disease, which includes the presenting symptoms of fevers, headaches, myalgias, and malaise. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis, vancomycin is used to treat bacterial infections, and azithromycin is used to treat respiratory and skin infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash, along with the history of camping in Virginia, suggests a diagnosis of Lyme disease. Doxycycline is the recommended treatment for early Lyme disease. Pyrazinamide is used for tuberculosis, vancomycin is used for bacterial infections such as MRSA, and azithromycin is used for bacterial infections such as pneumonia or strep throat.

We refer to medical references for help. The symptoms and rash are consistent with Lyme disease, which is transmitted by tick bites commonly found in Virginia. Doxycycline is the recommended treatment for Lyme disease. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis, Vancomycin for bacterial infections like MRSA, and Azithromycin for respiratory infections like pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash on the wrists and ankles, as well as the symptoms of fevers, headaches, myalgias, and malaise suggest that the patient has contracted Lyme disease, which is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. Doxycycline is the recommended treatment for Lyme disease. Pyrazinamide is used for tuberculosis, vancomycin is used for bacterial infections, and azithromycin is not the first line treatment for Lyme disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash and other symptoms suggest a tick-borne illness such as Lyme disease, which is treated with Doxycycline. Pyrazinamide is used to treat tuberculosis and Vancomycin is used to treat bacterial infections. Azithromycin can also be used to treat tick-borne illnesses, but Doxycycline is the preferred first-line treatment for Lyme disease.
